title: This U.S. Destination Was Just Named the No. 1 'City on the Rise' for Its Affordability and Job Market
description: A growing tech and health care sector is drawing young professionals to this Michigan metro.
content:
Finding a new job is challenging and takes time. According to data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median duration of unemployment in June 2025 was about 10 weeks. And while that is the median, some job seekers have been on the market for over a year. There is, however, a way to speed up the process, and that's by moving to a city with a fast-growing job market.

On July 15, LinkedIn released its new list of cities on the rise, which highlights emerging U.S. cities that offer both "vibrant job markets and growing professional communities." And it named the Grand Rapids, Michigan, area the No. 1 spot.

"A growing tech scene and booming insurance industry are helping Grand Rapids redefine its industrial identity while drawing a wave of young professionals thanks to its growing job market, bustling downtown, and proximity to Lake Michigan," reported LinkedIn. It added that the top industries hiring in the area include manufacturing, health care, and professional services, while the top employers are Corewell Health, Grand Valley State University, and Meijer.

Here, workers can expect an average income of $65,235 and an average home listing price of $524,195. This makes the price-to-income ratio of the homes slightly higher; however, according to Apartment Advisor, the average rent for a one-bedroom apartment is $1,250, a far more affordable option.

Other cities joining Grand Rapids include the Boise metro area in Idaho at No. 2, followed by the greater Harrisburg area in Pennsylvania (third), the Albany metro area in New York (fourth), and the greater Milwaukee area in Wisconsin (fifth).

For this list, LinkedIn explained that it partnered with Economic Graph to define "on the rise" cities, which included migration data, along with "year-over-year growth across each metric: where talent is landing, where roles are opening, and where people are moving (relative to leaving)."

LinkedIn also analyzed each destination at the metropolitan area level rather than just the city proper to "better reflect how people actually live and work today." 



LinkedIn has seen job applications grow by 45 percent year-over-year, with 11,000 applications filed per minute, according to a company statement shared with Travel + Leisure.

See the complete list at linkedin.com

Inside LinkedIn’s Cities on the Rise: How we identified emerging job markets
LinkedIn just unveiled our inaugural list of Cities on the Rise — featuring the regions where job market momentum and economic opportunity are growing. Learn more about how we designed the ranking below and check out lists in the U.S., Germany and India.
In today’s post-pandemic economy, many mid-sized cities are proving they can compete with the largest metros — attracting new talent by offering a more affordable cost of living, expanding cultural amenities, greater access to outdoor space and more.
This shift is happening alongside another major trend: companies are increasingly looking beyond traditional headquarters hubs to tap into more affordable markets and diverse talent pools.
This trend made us ask: Which cities are truly on the rise — both growing their local labor markets and attracting new talent?
Measuring momentum: Behind the metrics
To find out, we partnered with our Economic Graph team to define how we would measure “on the rise.” While migration data was a natural starting point — and our data scientists have uncovered insightful trends in where LinkedIn members move — we knew it wouldn’t tell the whole story. We wanted to expand the lens — to understand what’s driving those moves and where career momentum is taking hold.
So in addition to migration trends, we analyzed where jobs are being posted and where people are actually getting hired. But instead of looking at sheer volume, we focused on year-over-year growth across each metric: where talent is landing, where roles are opening, and where people are moving (relative to leaving). To qualify, a city had to rank in the top 50th percentile in all three areas. This approach helped us highlight cities with real, sustained momentum — not just the usual big-name markets.
To keep the spotlight on emerging metros, we narrowed our scope to mid-sized cities — excluding those with populations above two and a half million in the U.S. and one million in both India and Germany. (We also did a separate analysis of large U.S. cities, which you can explore here.)
We analyzed each city at the metropolitan area level rather than just the city proper to better reflect how people actually live and work today. Job opportunities, housing, and commuting patterns often span across city boundaries — and focusing only on city limits would have missed the broader economic ecosystems that define a region’s true momentum.
Diving deeper into local life
While the rankings measure where economic momentum is taking off, our data also helps paint a picture of what it means to live and work in each city. We’re able to highlight which industries and employers are fueling growth on the ground, giving job seekers a view of where demand is rising.
For instance, LinkedIn data shows that advanced manufacturing, healthcare and education are key drivers of job growth in many of the ranked U.S. cities. In Colorado Springs (No. 15) and Indianapolis (No. 14), established high-tech and pharmaceutical manufacturers are expanding their presence through major investments. Similarly, durable industries are advancing paths for further growth in cities like Reno (No. 22) and Albany (No. 4), which are emerging as information hubs fueled by tech infrastructure and research institutions. Together, these shifts show that smaller metros aren’t just gaining residents — they’re becoming magnets for the industries shaping the future of work.
Major investment from government and industry is key to many of the cities on the rise in India: infrastructure projects in Visakhapatnam (No. 1) are helping it emerge as a regional economic engine and driving job growth, while Raipur (No. 5) is being positioned as a future innovation hub, with semiconductor and AI firms starting up across the city.
High-tech industries are fundamental to the rise of many cities featured in Germany — from Dresden's (No. 2) position in "Silicon Saxony" with its growing tech and semiconductor sectors, to Heilbronn’s (No. 9) renowned AI-focused innovation park. Pharmaceuticals and research sectors are critical growth drivers in many of the cities featured too, notably Freiburg (No. 3), where the technical university plays an important role as an innovation incubator.
In the U.S., to help readers assess the lifestyle and affordability of each city, we partnered with Lyft to uncover the top destinations for local residents, pulled federal insights on average income per capita, and included average home listing prices from Realtor.com.
For professionals exploring their next move — whether it’s a new role or a new city — Cities on the Rise offers a valuable lens into where economic energy is building and where tomorrow’s opportunities may be taking root.

LinkedIn Cities on the Rise 2025: The 25 fastest-growing U.S. metros for jobs and new talent
Investing in your career can also mean changing your zip code. Nearly half (46%) of U.S. workers now live far from where they grew up, with many citing career growth as a driving force, according to recent LinkedIn survey data.
But that doesn’t mean you have to move to a large city to find opportunity. In today’s economy, companies are expanding beyond big-city headquarters to tap into more affordable markets and deep talent pools — and workers are following.
That’s where our inaugural list of Cities on the Rise comes in. We analyzed LinkedIn’s exclusive labor market data to identify 25 emerging metro areas where hiring is accelerating, job postings are surging and talent migration is reshaping local economies.
The ranking spotlights mid-size U.S. cities with vibrant job markets and growing professional communities — from Boise’s (No. 2) advanced manufacturing industry to booming tech and healthcare sectors in Nashville (No. 9) and Wilmington (No. 12).
Underneath each city’s mention, you can explore the top hiring industries and companies, as well as open jobs and people you may know in the area. You’ll find insights on the average income and home listing prices in the metro, as well as some of the top destinations for local residents courtesy of exclusive Lyft data, providing a window into the places shaping each city’s culture.
Whether you’re starting out, switching careers or looking for your next move, these are the cities to watch.
Check out this year’s list of the 25 Cities on the Rise in the U.S. — and join the conversation using #CitiesOnTheRise.

Methodology
LinkedIn determined the ranking of Cities on the Rise by identifying metro areas experiencing the strongest job market momentum and more workers moving in versus out.
Job market momentum is measured by the year-over-year growth in hiring and jobs — looking at the change in the total number of members who have added a new position to their LinkedIn profile, as well as the number of job postings, in a given year divided by the average number of LinkedIn members in that metro area. Migration is measured by the year-over-year change in the inflow-outflow ratio, or the total number of inflows divided by the total number of outflows, in a given year. The inflow-outflow ratio indicates how many LinkedIn members have entered a metro area for every member who has exited based on the location listed on their profile.
To be ranked, a metro area’s hiring, jobs and migration growth rates needed to be within the top 50th percentile or above across all U.S. metro areas, and not exhibit negative net migration over the past year. Metro areas with more than 2.5 million LinkedIn members were excluded to better highlight emerging labor market dynamics in mid-sized and smaller metros.
This analysis represents the world seen through the lens of LinkedIn data and is based on anonymized and aggregated datasets analyzing millions of U.S. member profiles and job postings from March 1, 2023 to February 1, 2025.
City Insights
Top hiring industries are based on the industry of the companies that hired the highest share of members in each metro area from March 1, 2023 to February 1, 2025. Top hiring companies are based on the employers that hired the highest number of members in each metro area from March 1, 2023 to February 1, 2025. Average income reflects the per capita personal income for each metropolitan area in 2023, according to the Bureau of Economic Analysis, and is rounded to the nearest five for clarity and uniformity (as in Grand Rapids per capita income of $65,239 is reported as $65,235). Per capita personal income is the total personal income divided by the total mid-year population for a metropolitan statistical area, which are defined by the Office of Management and Budget. Average listing price for homes in each metro area is provided by Realtor.com, retrieved from FRED (Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis) and each figure is rounded to the nearest five. Lyft rideshare data measures the ratio of rides in a city to a specific type of destination from June 1, 2024 to May 31, 2025.

On July 15, LinkedIn released its new list of cities on the rise, which highlights emerging U.S. cities that offer both "vibrant job markets and growing professional communities." "A growing tech scene and booming insurance industry are helping Grand Rapids redefine its industrial identity while drawing a wave of young professionals thanks to its growing job market, bustling downtown, and proximity to Lake Michigan," reported LinkedIn. It added that the top industries hiring in the area include manufacturing, health care, and professional services, while the top employers are Corewell Health, Grand Valley State University, and Meijer. Here, workers can expect an average income of $65,235 and an average home listing price of $524,195. This makes the price-to-income ratio of the homes slightly higher; however, according to Apartment Advisor, the average rent for a one-bedroom apartment is $1,250, a far more affordable option. Other cities joining Grand Rapids include the Boise metro area in Idaho at No. 2, followed by the greater Harrisburg area in Pennsylvania (third), the Albany metro area in New York (fourth), and the greater Milwaukee area in Wisconsin (fifth). For this list, LinkedIn explained that it partnered with Economic Graph to define "on the rise" cities, which included migration data, along with "year-over-year growth across each metric: where talent is landing, where roles are opening, and where people are moving (relative to leaving)." LinkedIn also analyzed each destination at the metropolitan area level rather than just the city proper to "better reflect how people actually live and work today." LinkedIn has seen job applications grow by 45 percent year-over-year, with 11,000 applications filed per minute, according to a company statement shared with Travel + Leisure. - About 20% of job-seekers have been looking for work for at least 10 to 12 months or longer, according to a new report from Career Group. Both candidates and hiring managers have a hand in why it’s taking so long.
For many of those on the job search, sending in job applications can feel like throwing résumés into an abyss. Turns out the hunt is as bad as it seems.
It can take an absurdly long time to find a job: About 20% of job seekers have been searching for at least 10 to 12 months or longer, according to a new report from Career Group which surveyed 765 candidates across many industries. Most applicants, about 30%, say they’ve been looking for four to six months, while 23% have been on the hunt for two to three months, nearly 17% have been on the prowl for up to one month, and about 7% were seven to nine months deep into the search.
The fact that nearly a fifth of professionals have been job-hunting for over a year isn’t surprising. Despite the labor market being relatively strong—the unemployment rate is low right now at 4.1%, and there’s been some job posting growth—there are a litany of horror stories on finding work. One job-seeker said he applied to over 1,700 roles, but didn’t hear a peep from recruiters until venting about the situation on TikTok. In 2024, 40% of unemployed professionals said they didn’t have a single job interview that year, according to a Harris Poll survey.
Findings like this can be validating for white-collar professionals down on their luck; it can be incredibly isolating and mentally draining sending applications into a black box. There are a few reasons why landing a gig takes so long nowadays, and they fall on job seekers and recruiters alike.
“In cases where it takes 10 to 12 months to find a job, there are many variables,” Susan Levine, CEO of Career Group, tells Fortune. “Are candidates realistic? What are their salary expectations? Are they flexible? Are they turning down jobs being offered to them? While the hiring process is taking longer now, that alone wouldn’t explain why it might take several months for a candidate to secure a role.”
Job seekers’ changing, and sometimes lofty, expectations
Applicants have the right to be choosy about where they work—after all, they’ll be spending a third of their waking hours on the job. But they may be shooting themselves in the foot being too picky.
Although the share of professionals thinking they’re likely to be unemployed soon hit a record high last year, job-seekers wouldn’t accept less than about $81,500 salary at a new role, according to a 2024 survey from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. It’s understandable that workers want a wage that is comfortable and livable, but it narrows the field of options they can apply to.
And even when job-seekers are turning in their applications, they’re leaving hiring managers high and dry. About 29% of Gen Z and young millennials have ‘career catfished’ recently, ghosting their prospective bosses after making it to the final interview round, according to 2025 data from PapersOwl. A good chunk did it as a dare, some thought they’d be better off elsewhere, and others admitted they “just weren’t feeling it.”
Levine says it’s imperative for job-seekers to be open to new possibilities. After all, careers aren’t always an upward climb, but rather a squiggly path to success.
“It is important for candidates in any market to be flexible, open-minded, and excited to explore opportunities,” she says. “The market is competitive, and to gain an edge, you need to be extremely well-prepared and genuinely invested in learning as much as possible about the companies you’re interested in interviewing at.”
But the job-seeking process taking so long for so many can’t fully be pinned on workers. Some eyebrow-raising hiring trends have been on the rise—and they’re out of applicants’ control.
The job hunt today: recruiters who ghost you and tons of interviews
There’s a reason why so many job-seekers complain about radio silence after sending in their resumes to hundreds of positions: They’re hitting ‘apply’ on gigs they have no chance of actually landing. About 81% of recruiters say that their employer posts “ghost jobs,” gigs that either don’t exist or are already filled, according to a 2024 report from MyPerfectResume. And it’s not just one or two postings that are fake. Around 36% of these hiring managers admit a quarter of their open opportunities are indeed ghost jobs.
Read more from Fortune
“Companies are trying to project, ‘We’re okay, we’re still maintaining hiring, that we’re still moving in a growth-oriented trend. In this market, our organization is doing well.’ That ties into why these fake jobs might be appearing more,” Jasmine Escalera, a career expert for MyPerfectResume, told Fortune. “It really is about the business, the bottom line, showing growth, showing trends, and how that can connect to maintaining profit.”
Not only are recruiters posting ghost jobs, but they’re also expecting more from applicants. It was once considered sacrilegious for a candidate’s résumé to be longer than one page—anything more would be a time-suck for hiring managers. But now, as more are using AI to filter top candidates to the next round, over half of recruiters now want a two-page résumé from applicants, according to a 2024 report from Criteria.
They also want to suss out job-seekers for a longer period of time; unemployed professionals have complained about having five, six, seven, or eight interviews before getting an answer. The standard used to be around two or three rounds before an employee is picked. Plus, getting an update between the interviews can take several weeks or months. The process is undoubtedly being dragged out at many companies—it’s turning employees off, and making them abandon hope.
“We often hear job-seekers saying, ‘I’m tired, I’m depressed, I’m desperate,’ using these very harsh words when it comes to the job market,” Escalera said. “This is one of the reasons why they are losing faith in organizations and companies.”

argos_summary: Finding a new job can be difficult, with the median unemployment duration in June 2025 being about 10 weeks, and some job seekers remaining unemployed for over a year. LinkedIn's recent report identifies Grand Rapids, Michigan, as the top emerging city for job seekers, thanks to its growing tech and insurance sectors, with an average income of $65,235 and a home listing price of $524,195. Other notable cities include Boise, Harrisburg, Albany, and Milwaukee, all of which are experiencing significant job market growth.
